title: Meet the maker: Richard Lambert of Windover
content:
Cyclist
Meet the maker: Richard Lambert of Windover

Windover is one of our local hills,’ Richard Lambert tells us during a quick break from mechanical support duties on a group ride in Germany. ‘It’s one of the most prominent points of the South Downs Way. We just love riding it, and it’s where a lot of our testing and development happens. It’s a local landmark.’

Together with friends and business partners Sam Watson and Chris Davis, Lambert creates bikes that are geared towards the trio’s local terrain, making the name an apt one.

‘There are lots of roads that go up onto the Downs but they just stop at the top and become dirt tracks. Our bikes are perfect for that because you don’t have to stop and turn back. You can just hop onto the bridleway and keep going.’

Lambert’s love for getting off the beaten track goes back to childhood when he first discovered mountain biking. He recalls lusting after the latest tech and suspension systems that were coming out at the time. And while he has dabbled in smooth surfaces, mixing with traffic on the road has never really agreed with him. So, when the gravel boom first hit, it was a pivotal moment.

‘I had a cyclocross bike that I basically rode gravel on before that’s what people called it. It really suited the sort of riding I like to do. I might start on the road but then see a path and think, “Oh, I wonder what’s down there.” When gravel bikes became a thing I really jumped on that. I just want to be able to explore without being limited, so for a good ten years I’ve been doing that sort of riding.’

When he’s not riding bikes, Lambert is working with them. He manages a local bike shop alongside his work at Windover – a balancing act that he admits is getting trickier as the brand expands – and he’s a qualified bike-fitter, with experience working in custom frame design at Enigma. That’s where he met Watson and Davis.

‘We would be experimenting with stuff and building our own frames – stuff that Enigma wasn’t doing. Enigma wasn’t really bothered about building off-road bikes. It was much more road-focussed. Eventually we all left, and we launched Windover properly last July.

‘I probably did somewhere close to 1,000 bike-fits at Enigma, including hundreds of custom frames. I’ve got a very strong knowledge of what works, what doesn’t and what fits most people. That’s the idea behind the Bostal.’

Horses for courses

The Bostal is Windover’s do-it-all gravel workhorse. It’s born out of the trio’s frustration with the tyre-width limitations imposed by most bikes. If the urge to stuff a 50mm tyre into it hits you, the Bostal will willingly oblige. And that’s without resorting to 650b wheels.

‘The other important thing for us was the geometry,’ says Lambert. ‘I often see people riding with the bars too low and not using the drops. Riding off-road is not about aerodynamics but being able to use the drops comfortably to have better braking control. We felt it was important to have a reasonably high stack height. It’s got a steeper seat angle than a lot of gravel bikes too.

It leans more towards the mountain bike designs you get these days, so is better for climbing, and it allows a slightly longer front centre as well, so you’ve got a little bit less toe overlap.’

When it comes to materials, the Bostal is built from Reynolds 853 DZB steel tubing with internal cable routing and a powder-coat paintjob.

‘Wet paint typically gives you a very nice finish, but it lacks durability,’ says Lambert. ‘We always felt it was a shame to have a fancy paintjob and then strap bags to it, scratch it and ruin it. I guess it’s the sort of people we are – we’re just not bothered about it being too showy.

‘The powder-coat paint is super-tough. You can basically drop tools on it and things like that and there’s no danger of it chipping. We just love the practical nature of it. You don’t want to have to worry about leaning a new bike against something and damaging it. It works well for us and it fits the brand.

‘We contemplated adding extra bag mounts and suchlike but the vast majority of people wouldn’t use them, so we decided to keep the Bostal as minimal as possible while still offering the features that most people will want. I think we’ve got the balance right.

‘Obviously there are lots of similar bikes out there now. We’re not going to try to pretend we’ve reinvented the wheel. We just wanted to build something that was reasonably priced, functional and built in Europe in good working conditions.’
